text: Knafeh (), also spelt kanafa, kunafa, kanafeh, and knafe,https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=hT- oEAAAQBAJ&pg;=PA209&dq;=Knafeh+(also+spelled+kunafa,+kunafa,+knafeh,+or+knafeh)&hl;=en&newbks;=1&newbks;_redir=0&source;=gb_mobile_search&sa;=X&ved;=2ahUKEwilp8vbsJuFAxUHWEEAHSf6Cj4Q6AF6BAgOEAM#v=onepage&q;&f;=false is a traditional Arab dessert made with spun pastry called kataifi soaked in a sweet, sugar-based syrup called attar, and typically layered with cheese, or with other ingredients such as clotted cream, pistachio or nuts, depending on the region. It is a traditional dessert in the Levant, and is popular in countries such as Lebanon. In Turkey, it is called k√ºnefe. Different variants of the dish exist in Palestinian, Turkish, Iranian, and Greek cuisine. ==References== Category:Cakes Category:Kurdish food Category:Middle Eastern foods
title: Kanafeh
